title.narrative: Integral Strategy For The Implementation Of Key Urban Development Projects In The State Of Quintana Roo

description.narrative:
The present strategy of collaboration defines the framework of technical collaboration between the Government of Quintana Roo, through its Agency for Strategic Projects (AGEPRO) and the United Nations Human Settlements Programme (UN-Habitat) for the Integral Strategy for the implementation of key urban development projects in the State of Quintana Roo.
Its formulation is covered within the Framework Collaboration Agreement (2014-2019) between the Government of Mexico and the United Nations Human Settlements Programme (UN-Habitat) and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (SRE) through the Mexican Agency for International Development Cooperation (AMEXCID)[1] and the official letter 0164/2018 where AGEPRO expresses its interest in establishing a collaboration scheme with UN-Habitat, through its office in Mexico. AGEPRO requested the preparation of a technical-financial proposal to develop an intervention strategy on urban development within the stations of the Tren Maya project, the Nichupté connectivity infrastructure project and a public space network in the municipality of Benito Juárez that starts by the development of design guidelines for La Equidad park project.
During 2018 and 2019[2], AGEPRO and UN-Habitat have held several working meetings to identify the approach of the collaboration. Through this document, UN-Habitat presents a working strategy from the territorial planning and public space perspective in order to define and design to attend specific matters requested by the counterpart. In particular, during the month of August 2019, both agencies held face-to-face meetings (Mexico City and Cancún) and several telephone calls to redefine expectations, technical scopes and budget for the development of strategic actions in urban development and public spaces, which are framed in this collaboration proposal.
Justification:
Correlations between urbanization and development
In 1950, only 29 % of the world population lived in urban areas. In 1990, the world urban population reached 42.5 %, and in 2009 it stayed at 50 % until reaching 55 % in 2015. Prospects indicate that this urban growth will continue in the coming years. It is estimated that by 2020, the global urban population will have reached 56.2 % of the total world population; 60 % in 2030 and 70 % in 2050.[3]
Mexico has been showing the tendency of being predominantly urban since 1960. Today, 77 % of its population is concentrated in urban centers and this concentration rate tends to be constantly increasing. The urbanization process in Mexico means that the number of its cities will increase - from 384 in 2010 to 961 in 2030- where 83.2 % of Mexican population will be concentrated.
This accelerating urbanization phenomenon presents an opportunity in terms of urban prosperity for Mexican inhabitants.
UN-Habitat has identified that the countries with the highest income per capita are those with the largest urban population. Likewise, countries with low incomes are those among the least urbanized, and this is a worldwide constant. On average, globally, high-income countries (41,539.85 GDP per capita) are the most urbanized (81.53 %) and those with low income (745.94 GDP per capita) are among the least urbanized (32.44 %).

Mexico is not an exception when it comes to this correlation. For example, Mexico City and Nuevo León State, where urbanization rates are greater than 95 %, are among the first three entities showing the highest GDP per capita at national level. In contrast, Chiapas and Oaxaca, where urbanization rate is the lowest in the country - less than 50%, are two states showing the lowest income per capita.Graph 1. Urban population and GDP per capita. GDP 2017, Urban population 2015.[4]
Source: UN-Habitat own elaboration based on data from INEGI. Gross domestic product by federal state, INEGI, base 2013 and Intercensal Survey, INEGI 2015.
Urbanization frequently comes with development and prosperity, especially in the cases when it is well planned and managed; this positive relationship is maintained in Mexico -even with its low control and planning standards- this is reflected not only in the GDP, but also in other social, economic and urban indicators.
As illustrated by the following graphs, in the five states forming the southeastern region of Mexico - Quintana Roo, Yucatan, Campeche, Tabasco, Chiapas - the average urbanization rate is 64.4 %, which is about 13 % less than the national average rate. These 5 states show higher percentages of illiteracy, infant mortality, teenage pregnancy, people with incomes below the poverty line and more marginalization. Similarly, in these states, indicators such as coverage of basic services, level of education, access to post-basic education, average household income, or the human development index, among others, show a decrease in accordance with the lower urban population rate.
This indicates that a well-managed urbanization with transparency and responsibility, can work as a strategy to increase well-being and quality of life. This is a fundamental premise of the integral development strategy of the southeast region of the country.

Likewise, UN-Habitat has highlighted in several of its operational projects that an adequate well-planned and managed territorial planning scheme, which provides for specific urban acupuncture interventions, has positive effects on reducing the exploitation of the environment, its ecosystems and natural resources. Such a finding seems counterintuitive, but the final political document of the Habitat III Conference "The New Urban Agenda" recognizes that "it is necessary to take advantage of urbanization as a driving force for sustained and inclusive economic growth [...], and environmental protection ambient". The same document notes that “by reorienting the way cities and human settlements are planned, designed, financed, developed, managed and managed, poverty and hunger can be ended, inequalities reduced, promote sustained economic growth, achieve gender equality, build resilience and protect the environment ”.
The signatory countries of the New Urban Agenda recognize “the strengthening of urban governance, with strong institutions and mechanisms that empower and include stakeholders in urban areas, as well as adequate control mechanisms, which facilitate greater predictability and coherence in the development plans promote social inclusion and environmental protection ”.
Under this logic, UN-Habitat has advised a significant number of countries in territorial and urban development as a mechanism to contain predatory practices in protected environmental areas. A notable case is the intervention of UN-Habitat in the State of Para, Brazil, in the Amazon Rainforest, where together with the state government it was proposed to create a local system of cities and urban centers whose function has been to create a belt of protection and responsible governance that will avoid or limit incessant deforestation in the region.
Purpose:
The purpose of this proposal is to generate a strategy for the implementation of transformative urban development and public space projects around strategic nodes in different municipalities of the state of Quintana Roo, particularly around the areas of influence of 3 (three) Tren Maya stations in the entity. The proposal includes the development of urban planning schemes around the "Nichupté Bridge" connectivity infrastructure project, as well as "La Equidad" park, which will potentially be a structuring vector of the public space system of the municipality of Benito Juárez.
[1] Reference is made to the meetings held between September 2018 and July 2019 with the team of AGEPRO.
